page.title: 03COTTAGE FARM (2)
page.content: The cows are milked in a milking parlour at six o'clock in the morning, and again at four o'clock. Ten at a time are taken in and put into pens. A teat-cup is put on each teat. A radio is turned on to calm the cows, and then the milking machine pumps the milk into glass jars. Iodine and lanolin is then rubbed on each teat to kill any germs. The warm milk is then taken through pipes to a large tank with ice around it, to cool it down rapidly, and it is pumped once a day into a tanker- lorry, to be taken to the{Jersey Milk {Marketing Board}premises. The herd produces about 48,000 gallons of milk yearly (218,000 litres),which is nearly 2% of Jersey's total output.
